choices.E: require software development experience to manage

questions.question_text: Which two features are characteristics of software-defined networks when compared to traditional infrastructure? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
C D seems to the best, most correct answer
Why is D
E is more relevant since to utilize SDN capabilities better - automation, integrations - you should have some soft of programming skills

comments.content: You don't necessarily need programming skills. Several vendors need you to understand the functionalities to deploy an SDN solution. You can tune and modify at your will the SDN solution but it's not necessarily compulsory. So C and D seems accurate for me.

discussion.content: I have doubts that C is correct. Overlay-underlay architecture is not only relevant to SDN

questions.question_text: When accessing the /device-detail endpoint in Cisco DNA Center, what is an acceptable SearchBy parameter value?

discussion.content:
D. is the correct answer.
It can be filtered using the searchBy query and it can be: MAC Address or Device Name value or UUID of the network device
https://developer.cisco.com/docs/dna-center/#!get-device-detail

Selected Answer: D
From: https://developer.cisco.com/docs/dna-center/2-3-5/get-device-detail/

Operation Id: getDeviceDetail
Description: Returns detailed Network Device information retrieved by Mac Address, Device Name or UUID for any given point of time

curl -L --request GET \
--url /dna/intent/api/v1/device-detail?searchBy=&identifier= \
--header 'Content-Type: application/json' \
--header 'Accept: application/json'

All the best.

D - device detail
https://developer.cisco.com/docs/dna-center/#!get-device-detail

D. is the correct answer.
It can be filtered using the searchBy query and it can be: MAC Address or Device Name value or UUID of the network device

AC I thinks is the most likely correct answer.
I am not completely sure about this, but Multivendor SDK support is a must and I imagine than then a "device package creation" phase, of someone willing to code the package to upload it to the DNAc.
In the screenshots here, there is mention of "device package deployment" but not "device package download" or "device profile replication".
https://developer.cisco.com/docs/dna-center/#!creating-a-device-package/check-for-updates
Source: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/collateral/cloud-systems-management/dna-center/nb-06-dna-center-faq-cte-en.html

No idea about trusted device profile update.

Selected Answer: CD
C AND D ChatGPT says so

Selected Answer: CD
A. Multi-vendor SDK support may also be a correct answer, but the most relevant features for adding legacy devices are C. Device package creation and D. Device package download.
B. Trusted device profile update is not an essential element for adding legacy devices, so it is incorrect.

From the course questions:
Which Cisco DNA Center functionality is used to integrate multivendor support?
--> Device Packs and the DNA Center Multivendor Java SDK
I have no idea on this one unfortunately, can't find anything online either. I'm tempted to go with Wocilon's answer, but if anyone else comes across an answer for this please post it

questions.question_text: Which two Cisco DNA Center features are needed to add legacy devices on the platform? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
I tried querying via python script Cisco AlwaysOn Sandbox, there is a snmpLocation parameter. So the correct answer should be:
- /api/v1/network-devices?snmpLocation=DC2.
- /api/v1/network-devices?family=Switches and Hub
- /api/v1/network-devices?managementIpaddress=10.222.10.35
- /api/v1/network-devices?softwareType=IOS-XE&softwareVersion=16.4.2

- /api/v1/network-devices?location=DC2. 
- /api/v1/network-devices?family=Switches and Hub
- /api/v1/network-devices?managementIpaddress=10.222.10.35
- /api/v1/network-devices?softwareType=IOS-XE&softwareVersion=16.4.2

Explanation:
-There is no "snmpLocation" query parameter and technically this can be configured using SNMP. 
- The possible option is family=cat_9k_1 which seems more like a series than a family. 
- There is no IpAddress query parameter (and doesn't make too much sense either)
- REST uses & for adding two parameters to the query.

Source:
https://developer.cisco.com/docs/dna-center/#!cisco-dna-1-3-3-x-api-api-devices-get-device-list
For Family possible options:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/cloud-systems-management/network-automation-and-management/dna-center/2-1-2/user_guide/b_cisco_dna_center_ug_2_1_2/b_cisco_dna_center_ug_2_1_1_chapter_011.html

The documentation doesn't actually show snmpLocation anymore:

https://developer.cisco.com/docs/dna-center/#!get-device-list

However I still believe Lyndongarcia09 is correct. Maybe this is referencing an older version of the API which did support snmpLocation, but more importantly the exhibit shows that snmpLocation is present. If the exhibit is stating it, for the purpose of the exam it almost doesn't matter what the real world documentation says, they're asking more about your ability to interpret the docs they provide rather than your knowledge of the real world docs

questions.question_text: Which path do calls begin with to implement Cisco DNA Center Intent APIs?

discussion.content:
We need to get the token first, before we can query. So the answer is D.
https://developer.cisco.com/docs/dna-center/#!device-provisioning/goal

Selected Answer: D
It has to be D. Firstly, you need to get the token first before running the intent API which is what /dna/system/api/v1 is used for, but secondly and most importantly, none of these other URLs actually exist. All intent APIs start /dna/intent/api/v1, which isn't an option
I agree that the answer is D. I don't know why everyone is saying A, there is no URL for DNAC API that begins with /intenet
this is tricky question - before we even think of starting any API calls, we have to begin with getting token, which is D. But A is possible too. Either D or A.

The answer is A.
Explanation:
Option B. No way Jose.
Option C. is close but order wrong: dna/api/intent/v1/ =! dna/intent/api/v1/ 
Option D. /dna/system/api/v1/ is used to retrieve tokens not the intent API
Option A. Is the only left which makes sense (sort of)
